prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4477, NGC 4596
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO J=1-0 measurements towards the nuclei of nearby, early-type galaxies with the objective of measuring the mass of cold gas within 50 pc of the center (treated as a point source) to a limiting sensitivity of 1e6 solar masses. The actual spatial resolution is a function of distance, but the required resolution is about 1.1" for these systems (1-1.6").

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: One of the basebands will be used for the CO observation, and the others are set to nearby continuum windows for calibration. Unless the CO lines are much stronger than we expect, we will average the spectral channels to 30 km/s for the CO baseband.

The synthesized beam of 1" corresponds to ~100 pc at the distances of these galaxies, so the beam volume will contain emission from material within ~50 pc of the center. The largest angular scale of interest is about 300 pc, where one might see gas in transit to a nuclear disk.

At a resolution of 1", the beam contains emission within a projected radius of ~50 pc for these targets. From other deep observations of galactic nuclei, we expect that the filling factor will be ~1 and the line width ~100 km/s. We will average channels to get to a channel velocity width of 30 km/s, and we expect to detect 2-4e6 solar masses, which corresponds to a CO intensity of 40-80 K*km/s for a 1" beam and a X_CO = 2e20 cm^-2/(K * km/s), at the distances of these galaxies. For nondetections, our limiting sensitivity of 0.09 K gives a 3 sigma upper limit of ~1e6 solar masses when integrated over a velocity width of 300 km/s. However, the peak line fluxes are computed assuming a line width of 90 km/s. The continuum flux is estimated from the X-ray and radio fluxes for the AGN.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The growth of supermassive black holes and their impact on their host galaxies depends on whether they predominantly accrete hot or cold gas. The most powerful AGNs are likely fueled by cold gas, but the fuel source for most AGNs is controversial and may differ between types. Our work on an unbiased survey of active black holes in early-type galaxies shows that cold gas is present in almost all active galaxies, suggesting that cold gas is a universal fuel source, but we lack direct observational evidence. In this program we will measure the cold gas mass within the central 50 pc of a representative subsample of these galaxies to determine whether it is correlated with the AGN luminosity.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
